item.title: An informative article on RWAs and the Spark Tokenization Grand Prix
item.dc:creator: Akira_Maker
item.description:
Hi everybody!

I’ve written an article on RWAs and an overview of the parameters: 1. Liquidity 2. Capital efficiency, now that the Spark Tokenization Grand Prix is launching today.

The article is meant as a learning tool for myself and others that might be interested in the development of RWAs.

I am happy to receive critique or remarks on the work and suggestions to further research.

The article can also be read on mirror here: Real-World Assets and The Spark Tokenization Grand Prix — Akira

Introduction of RWAs

This article provides a brief introduction to RWAs, highlighting their main characteristics and use cases. The final section focuses on MakerDAO’s SubDAO, Spark’s new initiative, The Spark Tokenization Grand Prix. The article is designed to inform and support the community and interested parties in understanding and engaging with this exciting development.

RWAs refer to physical or traditional financial assets that are brought onto the blockchain through a process called tokenization. This process converts assets into digital tokens that can be represented on-chain. While tokenization offers several advantages, it also presents some challenges. Some of the advantages include:

  • Increased Liquidity: Liquidity refers to the efficiency with which an asset can be converted into another form, such as fiat currency or a stablecoin, without a significant loss in value.
  • Transparency: All transactions are recorded on a public ledger, ensuring visibility for all.
  • Trustless System: Smart contracts automate and enforce agreements without the need for intermediaries.
  • Reduced Transaction Costs: Trading on a blockchain can significantly lower costs compared to traditional methods.
  • Fractional Ownership: High-value assets can be divided into smaller portions, making them more accessible to a broader range of investors. This approach has been effectively applied in tokenized real estate, allowing the general public to participate in such investments.

However, the challenges of tokenizing RWAs can also be significant. Sébastien Derivaux, co-founder of Steakhouse Financial, discusses in a podcast the early RWA work at MakerDAO and the challenges associated with investing in RWAs from a decentralized protocol. Some of the challenges highlighted in the podcast are:

  • Legal and Regulatory Requirements: Compliance with Know Your Customer (KYC) and Anti-Money Laundering (AML) regulations is complex.
  • Communicating Complex Financial Concepts: It’s challenging to ensure that non-experts can make informed decisions in a decentralized environment.
  • Institutional Adoption: Integrating RWAs into institutional frameworks faces hurdles due to regulatory uncertainties and infrastructure limitations.

Types of RWAs

There are many use cases for RWAs, with stablecoins being one of them. As the market for RWAs continues to grow, we can expect an even broader range of tokenized assets in the future. The following are just a few examples of what kinds of assets can be tokenized on the blockchain, with a lot more expected to emerge in the future.

  • Real Estate: This includes residential, commercial, and industrial properties. Real estate tokenization allows investors to own fractional shares of properties, providing liquidity and diversification.
  • Commodities: Physical commodities such as precious metals (gold, silver), agricultural products (grains, coffee), energy resources (oil, natural gas), and others can be tokenized to facilitate trading and investment.
  • Art and Collectibles: Tokenization of art, rare collectibles, and memorabilia enables fractional ownership and investment opportunities in traditionally illiquid markets.
  • Intellectual Property (IP): This includes patents, copyrights, trademarks, and other forms of intellectual property rights. Tokenization allows creators to monetize their IP assets and investors to participate in revenue-sharing agreements.
  • Equity and Securities: Shares of private companies, stocks, bonds, and other financial instruments can be tokenized to increase liquidity, streamline transactions, and enable global access to capital markets.
  • Revenue-Generating Contracts: Contracts with predictable revenue streams, such as leases, royalties, and licensing agreements, can be tokenized to provide investors with recurring income opportunities.
  • Deeds and Titles: Tokenization of deeds, titles, and ownership certificates for real estate, vehicles, and other assets can streamline transfer processes and enhance transparency in ownership records.
  • Carbon Credits and Renewable Energy Assets: Environmental assets such as carbon credits, renewable energy certificates (RECs), and carbon offsets can be tokenized to facilitate trading and investment in sustainable initiatives.

Source: Quillhash

Underlying asset: U.S. Treasury Bonds

RWAs can derive value from yield-bearing assets and can help stabilize protocols through risk diversification. One of the most prominent examples of RWA tokenization in the crypto space is the tokenization of U.S. Treasury Bonds, also known as T-Bills. These government-issued instruments are used to borrow money from individuals, organizations, and institutions to fund various projects, offering lenders a yield in return. T-bills are typically considered low-risk investments, as they are backed by the U.S. government, with repayment guaranteed unless the government defaults.

MakerDAO now has over 2 billion DAI invested in RWAs and has significantly increased its revenue streams by introducing RWAs into its portfolio. The development of the revenues can be seen in the graph below created by Steakhouse Financial, an ecosystem actor in MakerDAO.

The full dashboard from Steakhouse Financial can be found here. As shown in the graph, the decision to invest in tokenized T-bills has been a game changer for MakerDAO’s revenues. Since July 2023, revenues have increased significantly, and throughout 2024, they have consistently been above 20 million DAI each month.

The Spark Tokenization Grand Prix

The Spark Tokenization Grand Prix is a competitive initiative designed to discover and reward innovative projects in the tokenization of RWAs. The Grand Prix, which begins today (August 12, 2024), focuses on two key aspects: liquidity and capital efficiency, with an asset focus on short-duration US T-Bills and similar tokenized products.

Liquidity vs. Capital Efficiency

Spark and MakerDAO are seeking projects that either maximize liquidity for frequent rebalancing or enhance capital efficiency with higher yields and less frequent rebalancing. Although these goals might seem at odds, successful projects will find a balance, ensuring that liquidity-focused products still offer attractive yields and yield-focused products maintain sufficient liquidity. The focus on T-bills and similar tokens highlights the need for assets that can deliver consistent returns while being easily tradable.

In addition to these two focus areas, other criteria are essential to being competitive in the pool of RWAs:

  • Legal Structure: Projects should present a solid legal framework that ensures bankruptcy remoteness, compliance with domestic and international regulations, and clarity regarding the jurisdiction and relevant regulatory authorities.
  • Cost Structure: Applicants must detail their fee structures, including management and transaction fees, any potential discounts, guarantees on the fee structure duration, and additional incentives.
  • Liquidity: A crucial factor is how quickly and smoothly products can be redeemed for fiat-backed stablecoins.
  • Taxation: Projects need to explain the potential tax implications, ensuring transparency and compliance.
  • Strategic Considerations: The competition also evaluates the broader strategic value a project brings to Spark and MakerDAO. This includes how the project aligns with and supports the growth and diversification goals of these platforms, as well as its potential for offering or developing products suitable for Spark or future SubDAOs.

Liquidity in RWA Tokenization

Liquidity is a fundamental concept in financial markets, referring to how easily an asset can be converted into cash or another form of value, such as stablecoins, without a significant loss in value. In the context of RWAs on the blockchain, liquidity is especially crucial. The ability to trade these tokenized assets efficiently and at scale directly impacts their attractiveness and viability within DeFi protocols.

The focus on tokenizing assets like T-bills in the Spark Tokenization Grand Prix underscores the importance of liquidity. Liquidity enables the rapid rebalancing of portfolios, provides immediate access to funds, and helps stabilize the system during periods of volatility. Without sufficient liquidity, RWAs could become a bottleneck, limiting the protocol’s ability to respond to market conditions and potentially leading to inefficiencies or losses.

Challenges in Liquidity

Tokenizing RWAs presents unique liquidity challenges. Unlike purely digital assets such as cryptocurrencies, RWAs are linked to physical or traditional financial assets, which inherently have lower trading volumes and are often subject to complex regulatory requirements. These factors can make it difficult to create a liquid market for RWAs, as the transfer of ownership may involve both on-chain and off-chain processes, increasing friction.

Additionally, the integration of RWAs into DeFi platforms often leads to a fragmentation of liquidity across different blockchain networks. This fragmentation occurs because various institutional investors might prefer different blockchain platforms based on their specific needs for security, compliance, and transaction efficiency. As a result, assets can become confined to specific networks, creating “liquidity islands” where assets are not easily transferable or utilized across different platforms.

Solutions in Liquidity

To address these liquidity challenges, several strategies can be followed:

  • Cross-Chain Interoperability Protocols: Developing robust cross-chain interoperability solutions is essential for enabling the seamless transfer of assets between different blockchain networks. Protocols that facilitate interaction between isolated blockchain ecosystems can help reduce liquidity fragmentation and allow for greater integration and liquidity flow across diverse platforms.
  • Standardization of Token Protocols: Implementing standardized token protocols across different blockchain networks ensures compatibility and interoperability, which enhances liquidity. Existing standards, such as ERC-20 and ERC-721 on Ethereum, provide a foundation that can be extended to other blockchains, promoting harmonized tokenization practices and improving cross-chain operations.
  • Decentralized Exchanges (DEXs) and Aggregators: Decentralized exchanges that support multi-chain trading can aggregate liquidity from various blockchain networks, creating a unified marketplace for tokenized RWAs. This approach can help eliminate liquidity islands by enabling the free trade of assets across different chains.
  • Regulatory Clarity and Compliance Automation: Establishing clear regulatory frameworks and embedding automated compliance features within smart contracts are crucial for reducing legal barriers to tokenization and cross-chain asset transfer. Regulatory clarity will encourage more institutional participation, while compliance automation will streamline operations within the DeFi ecosystem.
  • Liquidity Pools and Incentives: Creating dedicated liquidity pools for tokenized RWAs and offering incentives for liquidity providers can enhance overall market liquidity. By rewarding liquidity providers, platforms can attract more participants, thereby increasing the liquidity of tokenized RWAs.

The Spark Tokenization Grand Prix places a strong emphasis on liquidity in its evaluation criteria. Projects that can develop products offering quick and smooth redemption processes for fiat-backed stablecoins, while addressing the aforementioned challenges, are likely to excel in the competition.

Capital Efficiency in RWA Tokenization

Capital efficiency refers to how effectively an investment can use its capital to generate returns. With the Spark Tokenization Grand Prix looking to invest $1 billion in tokenized T-bills, the focus is not just on whether to invest in T-bills, but rather on which tokenized T-bills to choose and how these choices can overcome capital efficiency challenges. Given that the Grand Prix emphasizes capital efficiency as a key criterion for successful projects, selecting the right tokenized T-bills becomes crucial.

Yield in Capital Efficiency

For tokenized T-bills, capital efficiency is directly tied to the yield of the underlying T-bill. The yield of the underlying asset depends on several key factors:

  • Interest Rates: When interest rates rise, the yield on the underlying T-bill generally increases, enhancing the profitability of the tokenized T-bill. Conversely, when interest rates fall, the yield decreases, potentially reducing returns.
  • Supply and Demand Dynamics: High demand for T-bills, especially during economic uncertainty, can drive yields down, while increased supply from government issuance can push yields up, affecting the capital efficiency of the tokenized version.
  • Inflation Expectations: Higher inflation expectations can lead investors to demand higher yields on T-bills to compensate for the reduced purchasing power, thereby influencing the returns on tokenized T-bills.
  • Economic Conditions: Strong economic growth and favorable global economic factors can lead to higher yields, whereas economic slowdowns typically result in lower yields, impacting the efficiency of the capital deployed in tokenized T-bills.
  • Monetary Policy Expectations: Market expectations regarding future Federal Reserve actions can influence the yield on T-bills as investors adjust their strategies, which in turn affects the capital efficiency of the tokenized asset.

While distributors of tokenized RWAs can’t change these factors, there are other factors that can be optimized to make RWA investments more capital-efficient.

Cost Management in Capital Efficiency

The efficiency of capital deployment in RWAs is also significantly influenced by the costs associated with the investment. These costs include management fees, transaction fees, and other operational expenses incurred throughout the investment process. High fees can erode returns, making the investment less capital-efficient. Therefore, selecting RWA products with competitive fee structures is essential to maximizing net returns. For example, lower management fees can directly increase the overall yield of the tokenized T-bill, while minimizing transaction costs can reduce the friction of buying, selling, or managing these assets.

The Spark Tokenization Grand Prix places a strong emphasis on capital efficiency as a key criterion for evaluating projects. Projects that can demonstrate the ability to maximize returns while maintaining sufficient liquidity and minimizing risk are likely to be highly competitive. By focusing on capital efficiency, the Grand Prix encourages innovation in the management of RWAs, driving the development of products that are profitable and aligned with MakerDAO’s vision.

Vision

In Japanese, the name Akira signifies brightness, clarity, and truth, principles that guide my approach to exploring the complexities of crypto, blockchain, and RWAs. As I delve into these topics, my goal is to demystify the intricacies of decentralized finance and RWAs, making them accessible and understandable. Through this series of articles, I aim to shed light on these subjects, providing clear, actionable insights that contribute to our collective understanding of the future of finance.

Akira

item.title: WBTC Changes and Risk Mitigation - 10 August 2024
item.dc:creator: monet-supply
item.description:
WBTC Changes and Risk Mitigation - 10 August 2024

Background

Yesterday on 9 August, Bitgo announced it is planning to transfer control of the WBTC product to a joint venture with BiT Global. This will result in custody being split across multiple jurisdictions including Hong Kong and Singapore, compared with current US based custody. Bitgo has disclosed that this change implements a partnership with Justin Sun and the Tron ecosystem; as such we can infer that Justin Sun will have significant influence or control over the joint venture managing WBTC. This change in control is expected to take place in 60 days.

This bears some similarity to the previous situation concerning control of the TUSD stablecoin, which was discussed in the Maker forum here. Since TUSD was placed into Justin Sun’s control, it has seen market deterioration in operational processes and transparency, including the resignation of the previous management team, suspension of real time proof of reserves, and several significant depegs caused by interruptions in redemption service. We have also seen other Sun affiliated projects show worrying signs of possible misappropriation, such as the substitution of Huobi’s USDT reserves with stUSDT, a Sun controlled RWA project that purports to hold a reserve of US treasury bills but has not provided clear audits or evidence that the backing exists. On the whole, we find that Sun’s involvement as a controlling interest in the new WBTC joint venture presents an unacceptable level of risk.

We also note that Bitgo itself seems to have had some negative developments recently, including a failed acquisition by Galaxy Digital where Galaxy backed out for undisclosed reasons. This, along with the unexpected decision to divest from the WBTC product, may be indications of financial distress within Bitgo, and reflects negatively on Bitgo’s counterparty risk. While some of the risk factors are somewhat speculative, it makes sense to err on the side of caution given the critical role WBTC collateral plays within defi.

Recommended Actions

Given the upcoming change in control, BA Labs believes WBTC collateral integrations on Maker and SparkLend present an elevated level of risk. BA Labs recommends the Stability Facilitator to propose the following immediate actions to limit growth of WBTC exposure, to be included in the next upcoming executive vote on Monday 12 August:

  • Core vaults:
    • WBTC-A DC-IAM line (max DC): Decrease for 500M from 500M to 0
    • WBTC-B DC-IAM line (max DC): Decrease for 250M from 250M to 0
    • WBTC-C DC-IAM line (max DC): Decrease for 500M from 500M to 0
  • SparkLend:
    • Disable WBTC borrowing
    • Reduce WBTC LTV from 74% to 0%

If Bitgo or other responsible persons cannot convincingly demonstrate that maintaining current collateral integrations are safe, we will consider further recommendations for parameter changes to protect the protocol and mitigate counterparty risks, up to and including potential full offboarding of all Maker and Spark WBTC collateral integrations.

item.title: LitePSM Job Post-Mortem
item.dc:creator: Dewiz
item.description:
Introduction

After the Phase 1 proposal executed, @BA-Labs and @Dewiz-EcosystemActor noticed that the configured parameters for the LitePSM job on the Keeper Network were causing an undesired behaviour.

It is important to notice that the issue did not put any funds in danger. The LitePSM job is a convenience service funded by MakerDAO to execute permissionless functions that take care of bookkeeping in LITE-PSM-USDC-A. At worst, they would cause a certain level of UX friction for users and integrators.

Timeline

  • 2024-08-05 6:04AM UTC: A member from BA Labs reaches out to Dewiz in a private chat raising awareness about Dai in buf not being minted and providing some more data and context.
  • 2024-08-05 6:05AM UTC: Dewiz acknowledges the message and starts discussing with BA Labs the topic.
  • 2024-08-05 7:36AM UTC: First analysis from Dewiz finds that the CRON_LITE_PSM_JOB at address is not workable, hence the litepsm.fill() function was not called automatically and Dai was not minted to fill up the buf. The fill() function doesn’t seem to be the problem. There is still 3M Dai in the litePSM, so the decision is to wait for more devs from Dewiz to confirm the findings and suggest a path forward.
  • 2024-08-05 8:16AM UTC: 2 Dewiz devs confirm the issue is in the CRON_LITE_PSM_JOB. The issue is not an accounting issue, but a configuration issue in the job, as explained further below. Dewiz confirms litepsm.fill() can be called permissionlessly to fix the issue, as it would mint Dai to MAX DC. The date for deploying a fix is discussed, but no decision is taken at that moment.
  • 2024-08-05 8:28AM UTC: litepsm.fill() is called by an EA and the issue is solved for now.
  • 2024-08-05 1:56PM UTC: a logic to define correctly the parameters for the CRON_LITE_PSM_JOB is defined, documented and agreed upon. Redeploying the job with the new parameters will fix the issue fully. It is decided that no code changes in the job are needed and redeploying is not needed before the LitePSM Migration Phase 2.

Root cause analysis

  • DC-IAM line (max DC): Set to 50M
  • DC-IAM gap: Set to 20M
  • buf: Set to 20M
  • fill: Set threshold at 15M DAI

The initial migration of 20M + buf set to 20M made the normalized debt (art) for LITE-PSM-USDC-A be 40M. Since DC-IAM line is set to 50M, the value of the target pre-minted amount (rush()) would be 50M - 40M = 10M. However, fill threshold is set to 15M and therefore the keeper network job would never be executed.

While the values were defined by BA Labs, Dewiz takes full responsibility for this mishap, because we failed to make ourselves clear regarding how the keeper network job configuration parameters would affect the execution.

Solution

For the reason outlined above, fill() had to be called manually by an EA collaborator, so LITE-PSM-USDC-A could reach the desired target debt of 50M.

To make it clear, the keeper network job has 3 threshold parameters:

  1. rushThreshold: the minimum Dai liquidity that is needed (rush()) in order for the job to call fill().
  2. gushThreshold: the minimum Dai excess liquidity (gush()) in order for the job to call trim().
  3. cutThreshold: the minimum Dai accumulated as swap fees (cut()) in order for the job to call chug().

Given that DC-IAM is activated for LITE-PSM-USDC-A, moving forward, Dewiz suggests that the values of buf and DC-IAM gap and rushThreshold for the keeper network job such that:

(gap % rushThreshold) == 0 && rushThreshold << gap <= buf

In other words, the value for rushThreshold should be a divisor of and also significantly smaller (i.e. 10x) than gap, which should be less than or equal to buf.

Also notice that when gap < buf, the following rule must be enforced:

(buf - gap) % rushThreshold == 0

Otherwise the last possible fill() would not be triggered by the job, since rushThreshold would not be met.

Final considerations

The design of the keeper network job is supposed to prevent calls to the bookkeeping functions of LITE-PSM-USDC-A to be called too frequently, which could cost a lot in terms of gas to the Maker Protocol. Having minimum thresholds for the respective calls to be made means that there could be up to threshold - 1 of needed/excess liquidity or non-ingested swap fees at a given time.

We discussed some possibilities to refactor the job, so the same issue does not happen again:

  1. Change the behaviour of the job if it is too close to the active debt ceiling or to zero, making it ignore the thresholds: this could bring back the keeper network spamming problem when these conditions are met.
  2. Add a fallback time interval in which the job would be called if required, regardless of the threshold: this would be a significant refactor, increasing the complexity and potentially the gas costs of executing the job.

For now, being mindful of the values set for the parameters seems to be the best way forward. If we have other instances of LitePSM in the future, the keeper network job will have to be reworked to deal with multiple contracts, and we might then consider adding option 2. above.

We also encourage integrators to bundle the swap with a fill call if the Dai liquidity available at any given moment is not enough. While this increases the gas costs of the transaction, it will mostly be applicable only to very large swaps.

item.title: LITE-PSM-USDC-A Phase 2 (Major Migration): Proposed Parameters
item.dc:creator: rema
item.description:
LITE-PSM-USDC-A Phase 2 (Major Migration): Proposed Parameters

Disclaimer: The data and information presented here is provided for informational purposes only, on an “as is” basis, and without warranty of any kind. This is not intended or offered as financial, legal, regulatory, tax, or investment advice. References to any digital assets or protocols are for informational purposes only and are not a recommendation or solicitation to engage with any asset or protocol. Any projections, estimates, forecasts, targets, prospects, and/or opinions expressed in these materials are subject to change without notice and may differ or be contrary to opinions expressed by others. MKR voters and MakerDAO governance retain full control over parameter changes and are free to use or disregard this information as they see fit.

  1. Introduction
  2. Proposed Parameter Changes for Phase 2
  3. Evaluation
  4. Proposed Scope Language Changes

Introduction

In this post, @BA-Labs initiates Phase 2 of a three-step migration plan intended to gradually migrate USDC from USDC-PSM-A and RWA014-A to LITE-PSM-USDC-A.

The estimated duration of Phase 2 is approximately 4 weeks. However, this duration may change depending on multiple factors, including (i) integrations, (ii) legal and technical aspects, (iii) the Maker governance process, and more. Following Phase 2, @BA-Labs plans on providing one additional forum post with recommended parameter changes for the final step of the migration process (Phase 3).

To learn more about the proposed migration process and its respective phases, refer to LitePSM (LITE-PSM-USDC-A): Introduction and Overview. To learn more about the previous migration phase (Phase 1), refer to LITE-PSM-USDC-A Phase 1 (Test Period): Proposed Parameters.

Proposed Parameters for Phase 2

BA Labs recommends the Stability Facilitator to poll the following parameter changes in next available cycle and include them in the next available executive vote assuming positive poll outcome:

  • Update the below contracts so they point to the LitePSM:
    • RWA014_A_INPUT_CONDUIT_URN
    • RWA014_A_INPUT_CONDUIT_JAR
    • RWA014_A_OUTPUT_CONDUIT
    • RWA007_A_JAR_INPUT_CONDUIT
    • RWA007_A_INPUT_CONDUIT
    • RWA007_A_OUTPUT_CONDUIT
    • RWA015_A_INPUT_CONDUIT_JAR_USDC
    • RWA015_A_INPUT_CONDUIT_URN_USDC
    • RWA015_A_OUTPUT_CONDUIT
    • RWA009_A_INPUT_CONDUIT_URN_USDC
  • Monetalis Clydesdale Coinbase Custody starts to migrate reserves to the LitePSM based on the throughput limits
  • Migrate all but 200M USDC reserves from PSM-USDC-A to LitePSM with a script executed in the spell (has to be done before PSM-USDC-A tin & tout is increased in the spell transaction)
  • The PSM-USDC-A liquidity throughput is decreased, the LitePSM is increased and potential liquidity remains constant
    • PSM-USDC-A
      • Tin & tout: increase for 0.01 percentage points, from 0% to 0.01%
      • DC-IAM line (max DC): Decrease for 7.5B from 10B to 2.5B
      • DC-IAM gap: Decrease for 180M from 380M to 200M
      • DC-IAM ttl: 12h (remains unchanged)
    • LITE-PSM-USDC-A
      • Tin & tout: 0 (remains unchanged)
      • DC-IAM line (max DC): Increase for 7.45B from 50M to 7.5B
      • DC-IAM gap: Increase for 180M from 20M to 200M
      • DC-IAM ttl: Set to 12h (remains unchanged)
      • Buf: Increase for 180M from 20M to 200M
  • GSM delay: Increase for 14h from 16h to 30h

Keeper Network Threshold Parameters

Due to DC-IAM and Buf parameters changes in the LitePSM, a new KeeperJob has to be deployed with the following parameters:

  • fill: Set rushThreshold to 20M DAI
  • trim: Set gushThreshold to 20M DAI
  • chug: Set cutThreshold to 300K DAI

Evaluation

Start Migrating Coinbase Custody Reserves Based on Throughput Limits

As explained in LitePSM (LITE-PSM-USDC-A): Introduction and Overview, the LitePSM is able to hold USDC in a self-custody address (pocket), where the LitePSM is able to freely move any amount of gem on behalf of the self-custody address. With this design, Maker is able to enjoy USDC rewards while funds are self-custodied on-chain without reliance on TradFi banks and RWA trustees, as is the case in the current Coinbase Custody (RWA014-A) setup.

Since the LitePSM can serve the same function as Coinbase Custody (RWA014-A), in Phase 2, we propose that Monetalis starts migrating USDC from RWA014-A to LITE-PSM-USDC-A based on throughput limits. The Coinbase Custody migration complies with the Clydesdale Wind-down process.

Migrate All But 200M USDC Reserves from PSM-USDC-A

For Phase 2, @BA-Labs believes that the LitePSM is ready to absorb the majority of existing stablecoin reserves. However, we recommend keeping 200M USDC reserves in PSM-USDC-A to continue supporting integrations that have not yet migrated to the LitePSM. These PSM-USDC-A reserves will be fully migrated to LITE-PSM-USDC-A in Phase 3, before PSM-USDC-A is offboarded.

PSM-USDC-A tin & tout

The main goal of Phase 2 is to absorb the majority of existing stablecoin reserves. The PSM-USDC-A will continue to be maintained only to support integrations that have not yet migrated. To incentivize migrations to the new LitePSM, we propose to introduce tin & tout fees of 0.01%.

DC-IAM Parameters

In order to migrate most of the reserves from PSM-USDC-A to LITE-PSM-USDC-A, we recommend:

  • Decreasing the PSM-USDC-A line from 10B to 2.5B while increasing the line of LITE-PSM-USDC-A by a proportional amount, from 50M to 7.5B.
  • Decrease the PSM-USDC-A gap from 380M to 200M, while increasing the gap of LITE-PSM-USDC-A from 20M to 200M.
  • Increase the LITE-PSM-USDC-A buf from 20M to 200M.

These changes aim to migrate the majority of USDC reserves to LITE-PSM-USDC-A while maintaining total PSM exposures at levels similar to those before the LitePSM implementation. The ttl (12h) will remain unchanged for both PSMs.

GSM Delay

March 8 Accelerated Proposal Changes: Prior to the March 8 Accelerated Proposal, the GSM Pause Delay was 48 hours. We proposed reducing the delay to 16 hours to be able to assess new parameter changes and react promptly, if needed. Shortly thereafter, we proposed to increase the GSM Pause Delay to 30 hours. This duration aimed to minimize the risk of hostile governance attacks via malicious spells, while still enabling fasted execution compared to the previous 48-hour delay.

GSM Changes during the LitePSM Migration Plan:

Phase 1: For the initial phase of the LitePSM migration, we proposed lowering the GSM Pause Delay to 16 hours. This adjustment aimed to provide a good compromise solution between being able to react quickly, while still being able to mitigate any potential malicious spells.

Phase 2: As we move to Phase 2 of the LitePSM migration, we believe it is prudent to revert to the 30-hour GSM Pause Delay. This fasted execution delay compared to the original 48-hour delay is reasonable given the importance of PSM modules for the stability of Dai. The LitePSM has undergone sufficient testing, while not many integrations yet integrated with LitePSM, and the parameter changes from the March 8 Accelerated Proposal are now stable.

Proposed Scope Language Changes

Assuming that the recommended parameters are approved by Maker Governance, the following values should be updated as illustrated below.

Governance Scope

Governance Scope - 10.1.1A

¤¤¤

The GSM Pause Delay is: 30 hours

¤¤¤

item.title: [Temperature check] DAI Teleport Integration Proposal
item.dc:creator: Viktor_Symbiosis
item.description:
Abstract

As Maker Teleport has not been completed yet and there is no teleport solution for DAI at this moment, Symbiosis.Finance can provide a teleport for DAI across supported networks. Other networks besides Ethereum, Arbitrum and Optimism could be added if there is a demand from the DAO.

Here is the draft proposal for a temperature check to see if we can gather enough liquidity and if there is demand for a teleport solution, given that no active solution exists so far.

Background

Symbiosis is one of the leading cross-chain solutions within the market and it offers a decentralized environment ensuring multichain liquidity protocol, which provides its users with features like swapping digital assets between multiple chains without changing the owners of the funds.

The platform is non-custodial and has a simple interface which makes it user-friendly and users can participate in consensus and sign transactions by staking SIS tokens to run a node within the relayer network. Symbiosis finance can facilitate cross-chain liquidity on a limitless basis where token pairs across different blockchains guarantee that they provide the best price for swapping their asset between any two arbitrary token pairs owing to constant monitoring.

Symbiosis is a portfolio company of Binance Labs, DWF Labs, Blockchain.com, Spartan Group and more investors.

Project Links:

Twitter: https://twitter.com/symbiosis_fi

Symbiosis App: https://app.symbiosis.finance

Github: Symbiosis · GitHub

Telegram:Telegram: Contact @symbiosis_finance

Medium: https://blog.symbiosis.finance

Audits: GitHub - symbiosis-finance/audits

Docs: https://docs.symbiosis.finance

DeFiLama: https://defillama.com/protocol/symbiosis

Explorer: https://explorer.symbiosis.finance/

Dune Dashboard (only supports 6/31 chains): https://dune.com/symbiosisdash/symbiosisv2

Summary:

Symbiosis is asking for an amount of liquidity from MAKER DAO to deploy DAI Octopool (Symbiosis single-sided cross-chain pool) among different chains to provide the ability to move DAI among all supported chains.

Currently Symbiosis has 6 type of Octopools across 30 chains:

  1. Stable (includes USDT and USDC)
  2. ETH (Includes wETH)
  3. BTC (Includes wBTC, BTCB, RBTC…)
  4. SIS
  5. LADYS
  6. 7.pufETH

All pools can be checked here: Symbiosis

Symbiosis is looking to deploy DAI Octopool among 3 supported chains: Ethereum, Arbitrum One and Optimism as it was on Maker Teleport.

Symbiosis partners such as Li. fi (Jumper), Socket (Bungee), Rubic, Rango, OKX DEX and more will be able to integrate these pools for DAI cross-chain transfers between different chains.

Benefits for DAI and Maker DAO:

Symbiosis will provide solution to easily move DAI between all popular chains similar how Circle CCTP works

Symbiosis will be the core provider in Li. fi (Jumper) OP-stack chains cross-chain campaign

Symbiosis will connect DAI Octopool with all popular on-chain aggregators and DEXs on chains supported by DAI Octopool

Symbiosis partners such as Li. fi (Jumper), Socket (Bungee), Rubic, Rango, OKX DEX will be able to use this liquidity in their systems and apps

Example of Teleport integration:

Live Example

Proposal Details:

Symbiosis is asking for initial liquidity that should be provided in these single-sided liquidity pools without lock-up periods:

DAI Ethereum pool: $80,000 of DAI

DAI Arbitrum One pool: $50,000 of DAI

DAI Optimism pool: $50,000 of FRAX

Integration Roadmap:

  1. Whitelist DAI token on Ethereum, Arbitrum One, Optimism and create to Octopool (cross-chain pool)
  2. Configure the relayers network to handle requests from DAI in multi-chain mode
  3. Connect DAI to Symbiosis front-end, API and SDK
  4. Integrate 1inch and OpenOcean to DAI Octopool on Ethereum, Arbitrum One, Optimism
  5. Launch marketing campaign (cross-chain quest) with Li. fi to popularize cross-chain swaps to DAI

Symbiosis benefits:

  • Integrated by Li. fi; Socket; Rubic; DODO; Etherdrops and more. All of these aggregators will be able to integrate DAI pools through Symbiosis
  • More than 30 chains integrated including all popular L2s and L1 chains
  • On-chain swaps supported through on-chain DEXs and aggregators
  • Opportunity to provide liquidity and earn additional APR
  • Low fees and fast transaction speed

Looking for the feedback and any questions.

item.title: Stability Scope Parameter Changes #15 [SFs, DSR, Spark Effective DAI Borrow Rate Reduction]
item.dc:creator: rema
item.description:
Introduction

Recent market events across major financial markets including crypto assets, which can be attributed to various factors such as BoJ rate increase and its impact on the JPY carry trade, macroeconomic factors, increasing political instability in various countries and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East that can have large impact on oil prices and consequently economic growth lead to decrease in borrowing demand and leverage in crypto markets which resulted in decline in external rate environment, including perpetual funding rates and borrowing rates in defi protocols.

In order to maintain competitiveness, BA Labs recommends slight reduction to all rates in the system. In the instance where market dynamics change, we will swiftly react and recommend further changes to the rate system.

Rate Overview

DeFi Rates

During last three weeks, defi Effective Borrow Rates declined and currently stand at 5.44%, measured by DeFi Rate Benchmark, which is a 7 day borrowing volume weighted average that accounts for supply rate users receive on their collateral and reflects live state in each market, based on actual collateral type used and corresponding rates.

Source: Blockanalitica

Funding Rates

Similar trend is observed in the perpetual markets funding rates, which currently stand at 1.98%, measured by the Funding Rate Benchmark, which is a 7 day open interest weighted average across major markets including BTC and ETH. During the market drawdown, they even turned significantly negative as long positions were liquidated or closed. ETH funding rate is currently still negative.

Source: Binance, Coinglass

DAI Dynamics

Total DAI Supply marginally decreased as a consequence of market drawdown since the end of July (-0.87% or 46.08M), while the majority of DAI is still being backed by crypto collateral, indicating small change in DAI demand. The small decline in DAI backed by crypto collateral was offset by increase in stablecoin reserves.

Source: Makerburn

Source: Makerburn

FiRE Implementation

We are still testing the FiRE model and making improvements in terms of specific configurations, but we are still using it as a general guideline for recommending changes to the rate system.

As seen below, the model suggests setting the Base Rate at 6.13%, which will be used in the future as a main interest rate in the system which all other rates consider.

Nevertheless, the trend in the model is clear which suggests that the rates should be decreased based on the current conditions.

DSR Changes

As seen in the chart below, the market drawdown initially had a negative effect on DAI deposited to the DSR, but the dynamic later reversed and is currently at a very similar level. DAI in DSR currently stands at 1.981B or 37.87% of total DAI supply. The new recommendation for DSR is 6%, which is still at a very attractive level compared to supply rates at various other protocols and we believe it will not have a large impact on user behavior.

Source: Makerburn

Feasibility Analysis

Estimated annualized net cash flow from crypto collateral backed debt will have non significant impact due to the proposed rate changes, assuming exposures and DAI in DSR remain the same.

Rate Change Proposal

BA Labs recommends the Stability Facilitator to perform the following parameter changes to the Maker rate system, which can go directly to the upcoming executive vote according to the language of the Stability Scope article 3:

Stability Fee (SF) changes:

item.title: Urgent: Accuracy Concerns w/ ALM Dashboard – Outdated Maturity Profile Calcs
item.dc:creator: RD20
item.description:
To assess MakerDAO’s solvency, we need to evaluate the total capital at risk (CaR) relative to its surplus buffer.

Current data shows:
-Capital at risk: ~$150m
-Equity (Capital): ~$57m
-Capital coverage ratio: ~38%

The liquidity profile appears healthy, with a positive funding gap projected after 1 week.
Source: https://dune.com/steakhouse/makerdao-alm

Asset-Liability Management (ALM) Dashboard: In 2022, SebVentures developed an ALM dashboard to assess MakerDAO’s liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) based on expected maximum outflows. This dashboard was designed to adapt traditional finance (TradFi) methodologies to MakerDAO’s specific context. Source: Modeling DAI maturity

Concerns Regarding ALM Dashboard Accuracy: The current Dune query for the ALM dashboard appears to be using outdated maturity profile calculations from June 2022.
To be specific, the query appears to be utilizing input values calculated in June 2022 (specifically, lines 48 to 53), potentially leading to outdated results. Source: https://dune.com/queries/3801574/6391842.
This raises concerns about the accuracy of the dashboard, as market dynamics and flows have likely changed significantly since then. Furthermore, this issue likely affects other metrics within the ALM dashboard.

Key Questions and Next Steps:
1- Has the methodology for calculating maturity profiles been updated since June 2022? If so, the ALM dashboard needs to be adjusted accordingly.
2- Are the values used in the ALM dashboard up-to-date? Given the dynamic nature of the market, it’s crucial to ensure that the dashboard reflects the latest data.

I welcome further contributions and insights to address these concerns and improve the assessment of MakerDAO’s solvency.

Thank you

item.title: Spark Tokenization Grand Prix - Parameters & Objectives
item.dc:creator: steakhouse
item.description:
Overview

As we approach the official opening of applications and the start of the competition on 12 August, 2024, we wanted to share some additional details regarding key criteria for how applications will be evaluated.

Paramount to Spark and Maker, are balancing the needs of liquidity and capital efficiency. To accomplish this, we are looking for applicants that optimize their product to fulfill one or both of these needs. Spark plans to utilize a more liquid product for frequent rebalancing and higher yielding product(s) for capital efficiency, with less frequent rebalancing. However, we expect the process to be dynamic and competitive. Liquidity focused products will still need to offer an attractive net yield, and yield focused products will need to offer suitable liquidity.

The amount to be allocated to the winners of the competition will be subject to how the products are scored based on the below criteria (further information to be included in the official application).

Parameters & Objectives

  1. Legal Structure:
    a. Bankruptcy Remoteness: Detail the legal framework to ensure the product’s bankruptcy remoteness. This should involve a clear structure that legally separates the assets from any potential insolvency issues of related entities
    b. Compliance: Legally compliant with domestic and international regulations
    c. Jurisdiction: What jurisdiction is this product offered out of, and who are the relevant regulatory authorities?

  2. Cost Structure:
    a. Fees: Outline the proposed fee structure, including management fees, transaction fees, and any other associated costs (e.g., agents)
    b. Fee Discount: Detail any reduction offered from standard fees
    c. Fee Guarantee: Disclose how long the aforementioned fee structure will be guaranteed for
    d. Any additional incentives or offers
    e. Terms to be confidentially emailed to GrandPrix@steakhouse.financial

  3. Liquidity:
    a. Redemption Time: Products should be redeemable for a fiat-backed stablecoin, with as little friction as possible, in the least amount of time possible. Provide a practical estimate for how long the redemption process could take in various scenarios
    b. Redemption Availability: During what time periods is the product redeemable, and at what notional value? (i.e., max = 24/7, 365)

  4. Taxation:
    a. Explain the potential tax implications associated with the product

  5. Strategic Considerations:
    a. What strategic value does your organization bring to Spark and Maker?
    b. What other products do you offer or plan to offer that could be appropriate for Spark or future SubDAOs?

item.title: Enhancing DAI Liquidity Provision with Bunni's Rehypothecation Features
item.dc:creator: GoodCookie_ETH
item.description:
Greetings MakerDAO Community,

Bunni v2 is designed to maximize LP returns on Uniswap v4. We aim to significantly enhance the value proposition for DAI liquidity providers on Uniswap V4 by using our advanced rehypothecation features to allow DAI LPs to rehypothecate idle funds (outside the current tick) to the DSR. We will also support rehypothecation to SparkLend itself. Announcement

About Bunni v2

Bunni v2 builds on the solid foundation of Uniswap v4 by offering several unique features that set it apart in the DeFi space:

  • Shapeshifting Liquidity: Provide liquidity in any shape, allowing for tailored liquidity distributions that optimize fee income and minimize impermanent loss.
  • Dynamic Liquidity Shifting: Automatically adjust liquidity positions using TWAP or Chainlink oracles based on market conditions.
  • ERC-20 Wrapped LP Tokens: Simplify liquidity management by converting non-fungible Uniswap V3 positions into fungible ERC-20 tokens, which can be easily used as collateral.
  • Rehypothecation: Allows idle assets in liquidity positions to be deployed into yield-generating protocols like the DSR, Aave, or Gearbox, maximizing earning potential for liquidity providers.
  • am-AMM: Optimizes performance by auctioning the right to set swap fees, minimizing losses from informed trades and maximizing revenue, with proceeds benefiting liquidity providers and pool managers essentially trading for free opening the door for arbitrage opportunities.

Rehypothecation: A Catalyst for DAI Liquidity

Our rehypothecation feature is particularly relevant for DAI liquidity providers. Here’s how it works:

  • Idle Asset Utilization: Idle assets in liquidity positions can be deployed into yield-generating protocols like the DSR, Aave, and Gearbox to maximize liquidity providers’ earning potential.
  • Enhanced Yields: DAI liquidity providers can significantly boost their returns by earning additional yield from these external protocols.
  • Increased TVL and Protocol Profits: Deploying idle assets into yield-generating activities benefits liquidity providers and increases the total value locked (TVL) and profitability of the protocols involved.

Collaboration Opportunity

We understand that AllocatorDAOs must actively engage in market-making against DAI, with at least 10% of their total portfolio. See 7.2.1.2: Cash Stablecoin Market Making Requirements. Utilizing some of the POL to do this on Bunni v2 seems reasonable, considering our advantages in LP returns. We also have additional features specifically designed for market makers, such as our open-source am-AMM implementation, Bid Dog. This would benefit AllocatorDAO market-making because, as the pool manager, they can trade without fees.

Benefits for AllocatorDAOs

  • Enhanced Returns: By earning additional yield from the DSR on idle DAI, AllocatorDAOs can significantly boost their overall returns on their holdings.
  • Increased Capital Efficiency: The rehypothecation feature ensures that assets not currently used for trading are actively generating yield, improving the capital efficiency of the AllocatorDAOs’ portfolio.
  • Automated Management: The process is fully automated, reducing the need for manual management and allowing AllocatorDAOs to benefit from additional yields without extra effort.
  • Risk Mitigation: Utilizing the DSR for rehypothecation ensures that idle assets are deployed into a secure and stable yield-generating environment, mitigating risks associated with more volatile yield opportunities.

Next Steps

We invite you to try our testnet, which recently went live at Bunni.xyz. There, you can get a hands-on feel for how this would work. We are excited about the potential for this integration and look forward to further discussions on how we can bring these ideas to life. We hope to go live on mainnet the same day as Uniswap v4.

item.title: Analysis of Recent Market Downturn and Liquidations in MakerDAO Core System and SparkLend Protocol
item.dc:creator: definikola
item.description:
Introduction

Due to the recent substantial market decline, the SparkLend protocol experienced more liquidations in the past few days than it had over the entire previous year, while MakerDAO Core system experienced the most liquidations since April this year. This is why we think it’s important to look back at the lending engines in question and analyze the capital flows during these liquidations events, as well as the user behavior.

This report will examine the liquidations from July 31 2024, to August 6 2024, focusing on the affected vaults, collateral types, and the financial implications in terms of DAI repayment and collateral liquidation. By analyzing these market dynamics, we aim to highlight the DeFi sector’s resilience and identify areas for potential improvement.

Market Conditions Leading to Liquidations

We’ve seen a significant market downturn in the last 7 days, starting with the ~8% BTC price drop and ~13% ETH price drop seen from 31 July to 4 August, only to result in massive selling during the weekend and into Monday 5 August when the price of BTC went below $50k according to CG from being over $66k on 31 July (a ~25% drop).

During this same time ETH experienced a ~33% drop (went from $3310 down to $2200). Up from that point, the markets have been somewhat stable, and even recouped a bit.

The recent selloff could be attributed to the Bank of Japan’s rate increase (the second time since 2007), which triggered a forced selling of global assets to facilitate JPY repayment, alongside weak US payrolls data indicating an increased recession risk.

This has led to over $1.1B liquidated across all major venues, 86% of which being users having long positions opened during this time.

Source: Coinglass

Liquidations in DeFi

Meanwhile, according to the respective @BlockAnalitica dashboards, during the last 7 days major blue-chip DeFi lending protocols have seen over 3400 liquidations executed on their Ethereum Mainnet deployments. This has resulted in a total of $442.67M collateral seized, while $417.44M of debt was repaid.

Source: Liquidation data aggregated from respective Block Analitica risk dashboards.

It is important to emphasize that major DeFi lending protocols, including the Maker Core and SparkLend saw no bad debt in the process of eligible positions being liquidated, indicating a robust liquidation mechanism ensuring the incentivization alignment, as well as the well-adjusted risk parameters put in place based on the current market conditions.

Maker Core Liquidations

The Maker Core system saw 44 liquidations in total, 2 of which occurred on 2nd of August, another 3 on 4th of August while the remaining 39 liquidations followed the drop on 5th of August.

Those resulted in $10.62M collateral auctioned and $9.4M debt repaid. The ETH and wstETH based collateral accounted for ~94% (69% ETH, 25% wstETH) collateral auctioned, while the remaining ~6% was taken from the WBTC vaults.

Comparing the numbers by the vault type shows that the highest amount of collateral liquidated came from the low(er) ratio ilks. ETH-B vault (130% LR) and WSTETH-A vault (150% LR) combined for a ~$6.5M in collateral seized, while ETH-A (145% LR) followed with $1.95M auctioned.

Considering the 13% penalty fees collected, the protocol earnings from liquidations in the last days stand at $1.22M.

Source: Block Analitica Maker Liquidations

It’s worth noting that in case of another price drop of 20%, assuming no CDP holders react on time to increase their collateralization ratio, there is will be 66 vaults at risk ($21.71M of debt in total), with the highest impact being on WBTC-B ilk as there are currently two big WBTC-B positions relatively close to LR of 130%, one with $1.18M debt at 160% CR at the moment of writing, and the other one with $677K of outstanding debt at 162% CR. Positive circumstance being that both of those positions are being actively managed.

Source: Block Analitica Maker risk simulations

SparkLend Liquidations

SparkLend protocol absorbed a lot more liquidations compared to the Maker Core system, ending up with 203 liquidations successfully executed with no bad debt.

Similarly to Maker, most of the liquidation events happened during the crash on 5th of August. A total of $35.56M worth of collateral was liquidated, with wstETH representing ~63% of those assets, followed by WETH ($7.34M, ~20%) and Ethefi’s weETH liquid restking token ($2.83M, ~8%).

When it comes to collateral liquidated per debt asset, DAI accounted for ~95%, which is in line with the outstanding loans having mostly DAI as a debt asset.

Source: Block Analitica Spark Liquidations

Beside wstETH/DAI positions, there were a couple of WETH/WBTC and wstETH/WBTC positions being liquidated as well ($1.64M in total) following the ETH/BTC ratio significant ~11% drop week on week (lowest level since April 2021).

Source: Tradingview ETHBTC

As a quick overview of positions at risk in case the market continues downwards, we examined wallets that would be at risk of liquidation if the price of ETH, BTC, wstETH, and weETH dropped by another 20% from the current levels.

Assuming no adjustments of their positions, there will be 128 wallets at risk, resulting in $6.15M collateral at risk (55% of which is wstETH) and $5.76M of repayable debt (98% in DAI).

Source: Block Analitica SparkLend risk simulations

Conclusion

The recent downturn further emphasizes the inherent volatility of the crypto markets and the importance of maintaining sufficient collateral to protect against sudden price drops. The Maker and SparkLend lending engines experienced a significant number of liquidations resulting in no bad debt for the protocols, which were all successfully processed.

Future Work

BA Labs plans to monitor user metrics to ensure the protocol’s stability. We will also provide further analyses of the most important dynamics and suggestions for tackling potential issues. At the same time, we plan to inform the community with this kind of analysis to get live data on user behavior and promptly respond to changing market conditions.

Disclaimer

This report is not intended or offered as financial, legal, regulatory, tax, or investment advice. References to particular assets or protocols are not recommendations or solicitations to engage with said asset or protocol. For financial advice, consult a professional advisor.
